ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: It is a great preview of departmental research.
Required courses for MCDB grad students; good way to practice talks and see post-doc talks, too
It's a class where you learn about everyone else's research and methods. I'd recommend it as a great way to get to know others in the department and find resources for your own research.

I would rather not attend this course, but it is mandatory. I would not recommend it - the talks are generally highly specific and only somewhat motivated. As far as departmental requirements go, this is acceptable.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: Good practice for giving talks on my research

The advance graduate seminar is an opportunity to present your findings to a general audience. Often times, we forget about the "big picture" when we prepare presentations for members of our field. The most useful part of this seminar is the question/comments from our peers.
It teaches me what other people in the department are doing; this is helpful if I have a specific technique or method I need to do, because then I know who to go to.
In addition to learning about aspects of biology that would not come to me normally, preparation of a good talk is essential for our careers, whether in academics or elsewhere.
It is just another presentation opportunity. That is fine.
